repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Loess Plateau Watershed
            Rehabilitation Project; First and Second Xiaolangdi
            Multipurpose Project; and Second Tarim Basin Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Second Loess Plateau
            Watershed Rehabilitation Project of China were as follows:
            outcome was satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. The ratings for the
            First Xiaolangdi Multipurpose Project of China were as
            follows: outcome was highly satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was significant; Bank performance was
            highly satisfactory; and Borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. The ratings for the Second Xiaolangdi
            Multipurpose Project of China were as follows: outcome was
            highly satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was highly satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. The ratings for the
            Second Tarim Basin Project of China were as follows: outcome
            was satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was highly satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            projects included: 1) The Bank needs to elevate its
            engagement in China's water resources policy
            discussions above the provincial level to emphasize the
            perverse incentives that are created by extensive
            agricultural water subsidies; 2) Monitoring and Evaluation
            requires capacity building and reorientation to measure
            outcomes and impacts; and 3) Much greater care is required
            in dealing with issues of attribution when estimating
            ex-post economic rates of return.

            INTENSIFICATION PROJ. (BANK-EXEC.),TF027027-PHRD-TARIM BASIN II PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),BBFAO-BB FAO,TF030572-JAPAN:CHINA - INTEGRATED ENV.

            IN TARIM BASIN, XINJIANG,TF027129-PHRD-TARIM BASIN II PROJ. (RECIPIENT-EXEC.)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a highly satisfactory
            project outcome, highly likely sustainability, high
            institutional development impacts, and highly satisfactory
            Bank and Borrower performances. Nevertheless, some lessons
            of experience address the following. Some technical lessons
            suggest the use of thick geo membrane under conventional
            lining materials to ensure seepage control, while the use of
            evapo-transpiration (ET) management and remote sensing is
            effective in assessing, and managing water resources. In
            addition, the community-driven Land and Water Management
            Plan (LWMP) process provides an excellent framework to
            address, in both structural and non-structural terms, the
            complex water supply, drainage, salinity, high groundwater,
            agricultural and cropping systems, land management and
            environmental issues facing typical irrigation systems world
            wide. Lessons regarding the institutional reform indicate
            that any process will only be delivered with strong
            political support, and the right enabling policy and legal
            framework. The change process to bring about inclusive river
            basin based integrated water resources management (IWRM)
            must include both integrated "bottom-up" and
            "top-down" measures. Other lessons reinforce the
            importance of developing mechanisms to define the rights to
            water for an appropriate natural resources and environmental
            management, compliant to the river basin management
            arrangements, achieved through a consultative and inclusive
            stakeholder representation.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Tarim Basin Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Tarim Basin Project for China
            aims at a) increasing incomes of poor farmers through
            irrigated agriculture development; b) establishing
            mechanisms for sustainable use, development, and management
            of water resources and land in Tarim Basin; and c) partially
            restoring and preserving the "green corridor" in
            the lower reaches of the Tarim River. Some of the negative
            impacts of the project are: 1) salinization of land within
            irrigation areas and natural areas of the green corridor
            (GC); 2) declining groundwater levels throughout the GC, but
            particularly, the lower (LGC) downstream of Daxihaizi; 3)
            increasing groundwater salinity in all areas and
            particularly near irrigation areas; 4) lack of knowledge
            about groundwater recharge rates, lateral flow rates and
            discharge rates/areas; 5) there is little information on
            fish and other aquatic biota; and 6) fisheries based on the
            three endemic species have collapsed and those species are
            either extinct or nearly so. Mitigation measures include: 1)
            groundwater monitoring piezometers should be installed
            within and adjacent to all irrigation areas. Additional
            piezometers should be installed at representative locations
            along surveyed cross-sections across the entire floodplain.
            There should be at least three cross-sections in each reach,
            i.e. Qiala to Daxihaizi, Daxihaizi to Yinsu, Yinsu to Alegan
            and Alegan to Taitema Lake preferably coincident in timing
            and location to sites where surface water is monitored; 2)
            water levels should be monitored every 3 months for 2 years
            to determine seasonal variations, then twice a year after
            that before and after the summer flood. Water quality
            samples should be taken on one occasion in the first year
            and analysed for soil salinity levels (TDS), pH, major ions,
            alkalinity, mineralization; and 3) fish monitoring is
            required near each of the major hydrologic monitoring
            stations along the river so that all parameters can be
            easily analyzed for establishing habitat condition. The
            locations should include river, wetland and backwater areas.
            Sampling effort should be quantified so that catch per unit
            effort can be defined for each species.
